name: Attack Total to Hit Target AC
author: HipMaestro

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
(not actually a game guide per se, but the only place i could figure to post it.)

This a chart that our PnP group has used for over 15 years. It may be helpful to NWN character builders who are attempting to optimize their design and would like to determine the limits of the finished product. AB 80 is about the highest we have ever reached, but the table is easy to extend further if you have a need to. If you find it useful, we'll reserve a seat at our gaming table fer ya.

How to Read and Use the Chart

The values in Columns 2 through 4 represent, respectively, the total attack (d20 + AB) for minimum dice rolls (2), average/median dice rolls ((2+19)/2) and maximum dice rolls (19). The average/median rating represents dice rolls of 10 and 11 (obviously, dice cannot roll any half numbers, right?). Dice rolls of 1 (Automiss) and 20 (Autohit) are furnished for reference in Columns 5 & 6, but each ignore the AC. The auto values occur 5% of the time, each. To use the chart properly, apply all enhancements, feats and modifiers you consider will be in effect during gameplay to determine the value of "AB" (Column 1).

Example
Scroll down Column 1. Find the row for AB=30.

The first number listed to the right (minimum dice roll, 2) in the row is 32. That means that an AC of 32 will be hit 95% of the time with that AB (30) with Automiss of 5%. Note: The 5% Automiss is a constant for EVERY AB since "1" is still a viable dice roll result.

The next number listed (average/median dice roll, 10.5) is 40.5. That means an AC of 40-41 will be hit approximately half the time and missed half the time with that AB (30).

The third number listed (maximum dice roll, 19) is 49. That means an AC of 49 will be hit approximately 10% of the time with AB 30 (5% (roll 19) + 5% Autohit). Note: The 5% Autohit is a constant for EVERY AB since "20" is still a viable dice roll result.

Consequences for NWN Characters
By applying the same analysis to each AB of a progression, one can further evaluate each attack (and flurry) of a progression.

A few observations should become obvious.

The AB of the primary (first) attack should NOT be used to establish the target, "hit-able" AC. In a 3 APR round, in that round, the AB of the second attack more closely represents the effective target AC. In the above AB 30 example, the AC 32 that can be hit 95% of the time, will only be hit 70% of the time (95% - 5x5%) with the second attack (AB 25) and only 45% of the time (95% - 10x5%) with the third attack (AB 20). The AB 25 will only hit an AC of 27 95% of the time, while the AB 20 will only hit an AC of 22 95% of the time. Just to check the estimated percentages another way, AB 25 will hit AC 36-37 about 50% of time, so AC 32 should be hit about 20% more often, which it does.

This dynamic reveals the tremendous attack consistency of the monk progression to continue to hit closer to an equivalent AC with each successive attack than with classes that use the standard progression.

Also, the advantage of a full AB extra attack from Haste or Divine Power (for example) greatly increases the percentage of hits on a target AC. The downside of these extra attacks is, however, that they follow the standard attack progression (-5 AB) when multiple extra attacks are used, even for monks.

So, the attack progression is a beast of mixed blessings. On one hand, the greater the number of attacks per round, the greater the chance to roll 1 or more Autohits in that round. But on the other hand, each successive attack is able to hit lower and lower AC for rolls from 2 to 19, the other 90% of the rolls.

This analysis should prove why it is so important to squeeze every possible AB out of character's potential for combat prowess via abilities, feats, enhancements and effects to reach as close to the AB cap as possible. Essentially, each additional AB is another 5% to hit a target AC, the only exception being the situation where the AC is so high that only Autohit will hit (AC > AB + 19). In that case, AB means NOTHING to the build's combat potential. Instead, learn how to roll more 20's *lol* However, it may be advantageous to settle for lower AB to gain other benefits. Just be alert to the fact that there are quantified consequences for the loss of every point in AB and the ability to hit target AC.

Therefore, the most meaningful consequence of additional AB is NOT to hit higher ACs, but rather, to hit a target AC more often. For this reason, any effect that increases AB by 1, like electing Epic Prowess, adding 2 more points to the primary combat ability or trading in that +2 weapon for a +3 version, results in a 5% better chance to hit that target.

There are other extrapolations that members of our group calculated which may be interesting, but they become too involved for me to explain adequately and are based on PnP. I am not the the sharpest tool in the shed, my friends.

Editor's Note
This chart only has value in a standard AD&D game that uses standard AD&D rules within standard AD&D environments where those environments have been balanced to utilize the game's dynamics. Custom environments can sometimes alter the game severely enough to become one that no longer reflects the dynamics intended by the designers of AD&D (usually because they create conditions that can NEVER be balanced). In that case... thanks for your kind attention!
